identificationModule.briefTitle: Evaluation of Brain Damage Due to Coronary Angioplasty in Percutaneous Intervention Patients
identificationModule.officialTitle: Assessment of Silent Brain Injury in Chronic Total Occlusion Patients With Percutaneous Coronary Intervention

descriptionModule.briefSummary: This study examines the formation mechanism and patient-related factors of silent cerebral infarcts, whose importance has become increasingly recognized in patients undergoing percutaneous coronary intervention.
descriptionModule.detailedDescription:
This study was produced from the assistant's thesis and was previously accepted as a poster at EuroPCR 2020. We recently completed the full-length article.

This thesis study was supported by Ondokuzmayis University.

armGroups.label: Chronic Total Occlusion
armGroups.description: Chronic total occlusion patients undergoing percutaneous coronary intervention.
interventionNames: Diagnostic Test: Blood serum Neuron-specific Enolase measurement

armGroups.label: Non-Chronic Total Occlusion
armGroups.description: Non-Chronic total occlusion patients undergoing percutaneous coronary intervention.
interventionNames: Diagnostic Test: Blood serum Neuron-specific Enolase measurement

interventions.name: Blood serum Neuron-specific Enolase measurement
interventions.description: The Silent Brain Injury ratio was compared by measuring the Neuron-specific enzyme level with venous blood sampling from both patient groups before and after percutaneous coronary intervention.

primaryOutcomes.description: Baseline NSE measurement to exclude non-PCI dependent brain injury. Elevation of \>20 ng/ml was considered as silent brain injury. Patients with basal nse elevation were considered as SBI and excluded from the study.
primaryOutcomes.timeFrame: NSE blood levels were measured 1-2 hours before the procedure.

primaryOutcomes.description: NSE blood levels were measured 12-18 hours after the procedure. Elevation of \>20 ng/ml was considered as SBI.

eligibilityModule.eligibilityCriteria:
Inclusion Criteria:

* CTO and Non-CTO patients undergoing percutaneous coronary intervention

Exclusion Criteria:

* baseline NSE elevation
* acute coronary syndromes or cardiac surgery within 4 weeks
* patients with a cerebrovascular accident
* intracranial hemorrhage
* and head trauma
* central nervous system tumor
* degenerative central nervous system disorders and neuroendocrine tumors
eligibilityModule.studyPopulation: Patients who were planned to have revascularization due to CTO in at least one coronary artery (CTO Group) and patients who were scheduled for single-vessel elective coronary intervention other than CTO were defined as Non-CTO (control group).
